Dancing about his newly healed wounds
Singing sweet hymns and chanting heavenly notes,
Rare harmony to greet his innocence,
That died, I died a mirror in our days.
But say, where shall I find, the men, the murderers,
That slew Horatio, whether shall I run,
To find them out, that murdered my Son.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What means this outrage that is offered me?
Why am I thus sequestered from the Court?
No notice, shall I not know the cause,
Of this my secret and suspicious ills?
Accursed brother, unkind murderer.
Why bends thou thus thy mind to martyr me?
Hieronimo, why writ I of thy wrongs?
Or why art thou so slack in thy revenge?
Andrea, O Andrea that thou sawest,
Me for thy friend Horatio handled thus,
And him for me thus causeless murdered.
Well, force perforce, I must constrain myself,
To patience, and apply me to the time,
Till heaven as I have hoped shall set me free.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.l: Come Madam Bel-imperia, this may not be,

div1.stage: Enter Lorenzo, Balthazar, and the Page.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Boy, talk no further, thus far things go well,
Thou art assured that thou sawest him dead?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Or else my Lord I live not.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That is enough.
As for his resolution in his end,
Leave that to him with whom he sojourns now.
Here, take my ring, and give it Christophill,
And bid him let my Sister be enlarged,
And bring her hither straight.
This that I did was for a policy,
To smooth and keep the murder secret,
Which as a nine days wonder being over-blown,
My gentle Sister will I now enlarge.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: And time Lorenzo, for my Lord the Duke,
You heard enquired for her yesternight.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why? and my Lord, I hope you heard me say,
Sufficient reason, why she kept away.
But that is all one, my Lord, you love her?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then in your love beware, deal cunningly,
Salve all suspicions, only sooth me up,
And if she hap to stand on terms with us,
As for her sweet heart, and concealment so,
Jest with her gently, under fained jest
Are things concealed, that else would breed unrest.
But here she comes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now Sister.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sister, no thou art no brother, but an enemy.
Else wouldst thou not have used thy Sister so,
First, to affright me with thy weapons drawn,
And with extremes abuse my company:
And then to hurry me like whirlwinds rage,
A midst a crew of thy confederates:
And clap me up where none might come at me,
Nor I at any to reveal my wrongs.
What madding fury did possess thy wits?
Or wherein is it that I offended thee?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Advise you better Bel-imperia,
For I have done you no disparagement:
Unless by more discretion than deserved,
I sought to save your honour and mine own.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine honour, why Lorenzo, wherein is it,
That I neglect my reputation so,
As you, or any need to rescue it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: His highness and my Father were resolved,
To come confer with old Hieronimo,
Concerning certain matters of estate,
That by the Viceroy was determined.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And wherein was mine honour touched in that?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Have patience Bel-imperia, hear the rest.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Me next in sight as messenger they sent,
To give him notice that they were so nigh:
Now when I came consorted with the Prince,
And unexpected in an Arbour there,
Found Bel-imperia with Horatio.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why then remembering that old disgrace,
Which you for Don Andrea had endured,
And now were likely longer to sustain,
By being found so meanly accompanied:
Thought rather, for I knew no readier mean,
To thrust Horatio forth my fathers way.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: And carry you obscurely some where else,
Lest that his highness should have found you there.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Even so my Lord, and you are witness,
That this is true which he entreateth of.
You (gentle brother) forged this for my sake,
And you my Lord, were made his instrument:
A work of worth, worthy the noting too.
But what is the cause that you concealed me since?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your melancholy Sister since the news,
Of your first favourite Don Andreas death,
My Fathers old wrath hath exasperate.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: And better was it for you being in disgrace,
To absent yourself and give his fury place.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But why had I no notice of his ire?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That were to add more fuel to your fire.
Who burnt like Atna, for Andreas loss.

sp.speaker: B
sp.l: Hath not my Father then enquired for me?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sister he hath, and thus excused I thee.
But Bel-imperia, see the gentle prince,
Look on thy love, behold young Balthazar.
Whose passions by thy presence are increased,
And in whose melancholy thou mayst see,
Thy hate, his love: thy flight, his following thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Brother you are become an Orator,
I know not I, by what experience,
Too politic for me, past all compare,
Since last I saw you, but content yourself,
The Prince is meditating higher things,

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: It is of thy beauty then that conquers Kings.
Of those thy tresses Ariadnes twines,
Where with my liberty thou hast surprised
Of that thine ivory front my sorrows map,
Wherein I see no haven to rest my hope.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To love, and fear, and both at once my Lord,
In my conceit, are things of more import,
Than women's wits are to be busied with.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: It is I that love.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Bel-imperia.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But I that fear.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Bel-imperia.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Fear yourself?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Aye brother.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: As those, that what they love, are loath, and fear to lose.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Then fair, let Balthazar your keeper be,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No, Balthazar doth fear as well as we.

l.foreign: Est tremulo metui pauidum iunxeve timorem
Et vanum stolidae proditionis opus.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay, and you argue things so cunningly,
We will go continue this discourse at Court,

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Led by the lodestar of her heavenly looks,
Wends poor oppressed Baltbazar,
As over the mountains walks the wanderer,
Uncertain to effect his Pilgrimage.

div1.stage: Enter two Portingales, and Hieronimo meets them.

sp.l: By your leave Sir.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: It is neither as you think, nor as you think,
Nor as you think: you are wide all:
These slippers are not mine, they were my son Horatio
My son, and what is a son?
A thing begot within a pair of minutes, there about:
A lump bred up in darkness, and doth serve
To ballast these light creatures we call Women:
And at nine months end, creeps forth to light.
What is there yet in a son?
To make a farther dote, rave, or run mad.
Being born, it pouts, cries, and breeds teeth.
What is there yet in a son? He must be fed,
Be taught to go, and speak Aye or yet.
Why might not a man love a Calf as well?
Or melt in passion over a frisking Kid,
As for a son, methinks a young Bacon,
Or a fine little smooth Horse-colt
Should move a man, as much as doth a son.
For one of these in very little time,
Will grow to some good use, whereas a son,
The more he grows in stature and in years,
The more unsquared, unbevilled he appears,
Reckons his parents among the rank of fools,
Strikes care upon their heads with his mad riots
Makes them look old, before they meet with age:
This is a son: And what a loss were this, considered truly.
O but my Horatio, grew out of these
Insatiate humours: He loved his loving parents,
He was my comfort, and his mothers joy,
The very arm that did hold up our house,
Our hopes were stored up in him.
None but a damned murderer could hate him:
He had not seen the back of nineteen year,
When his strong arm unhorsed the proud Prince Balthazar,
And his great mind too full of Honour,
Took him us to mercy, that valiant, but noble Portingale
Well, heaven is heaven still
And there is Nemesis and Furies
And things called whips,
And they sometimes do meet with murderers,
They do not always scape, that is some comfort.
Aye, Aye, Aye, and then time steals on: and steals, and steals
Till violence leaps forth like thunder
Wrapped in a ball of fire,
And so doth bring confusion to them all.
Good leave have you, nay, I pray you go,
For I will leave you, if you can leave me so.
Pray you which is the next way to my Lord. the Dukes.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: The next way from me.
To his house we mean.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: O hard by, it is yon house that you see.
You could not tell us, if his Son were there.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Who, my Lord Lorenzo?
Aye Sir.

div1.stage: He goeth in at one doore and comes out at another.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: O forbear, for other talk for us far fitter were.
But if you be importunate to know,
The way to him, and where to find him out,
Then list to me, and I will resolve your doubt.
There is a path upon your left hand side,
That leadeth from a guilty conscience,
Unto a forest of distrust and fear.
A darksome place and dangerous to pass,
There shall you meet with melancholy thoughts,
Whose baleful humours if you but uphold,
It will conduct you to despair and death:
Whose rocky cliffs, when you have once beheld,
Within a huge dale of lasting night,
That kindled with the worlds iniquities,
Doth cast up filthy and detested fumes.
Not far from thence where murderers have built,
A habitation for their cursed soul:
There in a brazen Cauldron fixed by Ioue,
In his fell wrath upon a sulphur flame:
Yourselves shall find Lorenzo bathing him,
In boiling lead and blood of innocents.
Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: why ha, ha, ha. Farewell good ha, ha, ha.
Doubtless this man is passing lunatic,
Or imperfection of his age doth make him dote.
Come, let us away to seek my Lord the Duke.

div1.stage: Enter Hieronimo with a Ponyard in one hand, and a Rope in the other.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Now Sir, perhaps I come and see the King,
The King sees me, and fain would hear my suit.
Why is not this a strange and seld seen thing.
That standers by with toys should strike me mute.
Go too, I see their shifts, and say no more,
Hieronimo, it is time for thee to trudge.
Down by the dale that flows with purple gore,
Standeth a fiery Tower, there sits a judge,
Upon a seat of steel and molten brass:
And twixt his teeth he holds a fire-brand,
That leads unto the lake where hell doth stand.
Away Hieronimo to him be gone:
He will do thee justice for Horatios death.
Turn down this path thou shalt be with him straight,
Or this, and then thou needst not take thy breath.
This way, or that way: soft and fair, not so:
For if I hang or kill myself, let us know
Who will revenge Horatios murther then?
No, no, fie no: pardon me, I will none of that:
sp.stage: He flings away the dagger and halter.
sp.l: This way I will take, and this way comes the King,
And here I will have a fling at him that is flat.
And Baltbazar I will be with thee to bring,
And thee Lorenzo, here is the King, nay, stay,
And here, I here, there goes the hare away.

div1.stage: Enter King, Embassador, Castile, and Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now show Ambassador what our Viceroy saith,
Hath he received the articles we sent?

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Justice, O justice to Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Back, seest thou not the King is busy?

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: O, is he so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who is he that interrupts our business?

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Not I, Hieronimo beware, go by, go by.

sp.speaker: Embas.
sp.l: Renowned King he hath received and read,
Thy kingly proffers, and thy promised league,
And as a man extremely overjoyed,
To hear his Son so Princely entertained,
Whose death he had so solemnly bewailed.
This for thy further satisfaction,
And kingly love, he kindly lets thee know:
First, for the marriage of his Princely Son,
With Bel-imperia thy beloved Niece,
The news are more delightful to his soul,
Than myrrh or incense to the offended heavens.
In person therefore will he come himself,
To see the marriage rites solemnised,
And in the presence of the Court of Spaine,
To knit a sure inexecrable band,
Of Kingly love, and everlasting league,
Betwixt the Crowns of Spaine and Portingale.
There will he give his Crown to Balthazar,
And make a Queen of Bel-imperia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Brother, how like you this our Viceroys love?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: No doubt my Lord, it is an argument
Of honourable care to keep his friend,
And wondrous zeal to Balthazar his son:
Nor am I least indebted to his grace,
That bends his liking to my daughter thus.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Now last (dread Lord) here hath his highness sent,
Although he send not that his Son return,
His ransom due to Don Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Horatio, who calls Horatio?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And well remembered, thank his Majesty.
Here, see it given to Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Justice, O justice, justice, gentle King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who is that? Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Justice, O justice: O my son, my son,
My Son whom nought can ransom or redeem

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hieronimo, you are not well advised.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Away Lorenzo hinder me no more,
For thou hast made me bankrupt of my bliss:
Give me my son, you shall not ransom him.
Away, I will rip the bowels of the earth,
And Ferry over to the Elysian plains,
And bring my Son to show his deadly wounds.
Stand from about me, I will make a pickaxe of my poniard,
And here surrender up my Marshalship:
For I will go marshall up the fiends in hell,
To be avenged on you all for this.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What means this outrage? will none of you restrain his fury.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Nay soft and fair, you shall not need to strive,
Needs must he go that the devils drive.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What accident hath happed Hieronimo?
I have not seen him to demean him so.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, he is with extreme pride,
Conceived of young Horatio his Son,
And covetous of having to himself,
The ransom of the young Prince Balthazar
Distract and in a manner lunatic.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Believe me Nephew we are sorry for it,
This is the love that Fathers bear their sons:
But gentle brother, go give to him this gold,
The Princes ransom, let him have his due,
For what he hath Horatio shall not want,
Happily Hieronimo hath need thereof.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But if he be thus haplessly distract,
It is requisite his office be resigned,
And given to one of more discretion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We shall increase his melancholy so.
It is best that we see further in it first:
Till when, ourself will exempt the place.
And Brother, now bring in the Ambassador,
That he may be a witness of the match.
Twixt Balthazar and Bel-imperia.
And that we may prefix a certain time.
Wherein the marriage shall be solemnised,
That we may have thy Lord the Vice-roy here.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Therein your highness highly shall content,
His Majesty, that longs to hear from hence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: On then, and hear you Lord Ambassador.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I wonder Pedro, why our Master thus
At midnight sends us with our Torches light,
When man and bird and beast are all at rest,
Save those that watch for rape and bloody murder?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Iaques, know thou that our Master's mind
Is much distraught since his Horatio died,
And now his aged years should sleep in rest
His heart in quiet, like a desperate man
Grows lunatic and childish for his Son:
Sometimes as he doth at his table sit
He speaks as if Horatio stood by him,
Then starting in a rage, falls on the earth,
Cries out Horatio, Where is my Horatio?
So that with extreme grief and cutting sorrow
There is not left in him one inch of man:
See where he comes.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: I pry through every crevice of each wall
Look on each tree, and search through every brake,
Beat at the bushes, stamp our grandam earth,
Dive in the water, and flare up to heaven,
Yet cannot I behold my son Horatio
How now, Who is there, spirits, spirits?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: We are your servants that attend you sir.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: What make you with your torches in the dark.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You bid us light them, and attend you here.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: No, no, you are deceived, not I, you are deceived,
Was I so mad to bid you light your torches now,
Light me your torches at the mid of noon,
When as the Sun-God rides in all his glory:
Light me your torches then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Then we burn day light.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Let it be burnt, night is a murderous slut,
That would not have her treasons to be seen,
And yonder pale faced He-cat there, the Moon,
Doth give consent to that is done in darkness
And all those Stars that gaze upon her face,
Are aglets on her sleeve pins on her train,
And those that should be powerful and divine.
Do sleep in darkness when they most should shine.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Provoke them not fair sir, with tempting words,
The heavens are gracious, and your miseries and sorrow,
Makes you speak you know not what.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Villain, thou liest, and thou doest naught
But tell me I am mad, thou liest, I am not mad.
I know thee to be Pedro, and he Iaques,
I will prove it to thee, and were I mad, how could I?
Where was she that same night when my Hor. was murdered?
She should have shone: Search thou the book,
Had the Moon shone, in my boy's face (there was a kind of grace
That I know) nay, I do know, had the murderer seen him,
His weapon would have fallen and cut the earth,
Had he been framed of naught but blood and death.
Alack when mischief doth it knows not what,
What shall we say to mischief?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Dear Hieronimo, come in a doors.
O, seek not means so to increase thy sorrow

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Indeed, Isabella we do nothing here,
I do not cry, ask Pedro and ask Iaques,
Not I indeed, we are very merry, very merry.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How, be merry here, be merry here.
Is not this the place, and this the very tree,
Where my Horatio died, where he was murdered?

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Was, do not say what: let her weep it out
This was the tree, I set it of a kernel,
And when our hot Spaine could not let it grow
But that the infant and the human sap
Began to wither, duly twice a morning,
Would I be sprinkling it with fountain water,
At last it grew, and grew, and bore and bore,
Till at the length it grew a gallows, and did bear our son.
It bore thy fruit and mine: O wicked, wicked plant.
sp.stage: One knockes within at the doore.
sp.l: See who knock there.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.l: It is a painter sir.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Bid him come in, and paint some comfort,
For surely there is none lives but painted comfort
Let him come in, one knows not what may chance,
Gods will, that I should set this tree,
But even so matters, ungrateful servants rear from nought
And then they hate them that did bring them up.

sp.speaker: Pain
sp.l: God bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Wherefore, why, thou scornful villain.
How, where, or by what means should I be blessed,

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What wouldst thou have good fellow.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Justice, Madam.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: O ambitious beggar, wouldst thou have that
That lives not in the world,
Why all the undelved mines cannot buy
An ounce of justice, it is a jewel so inestimable:
I tell thee, God hath engrossed all justice in his hands,
And there is none, but what comes from him.

sp.speaker: Pai.
sp.l: O then I see that God must right me for my murdered son

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: How, was thy son murdered?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Aye, sir, no man did hold a son so dear.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: What not as thine? that is a lie,
As massy as the earth I had a son,
Whose least unvalued hair did weigh
A thousand of thy sons and he was murdered.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Alas, sir, I had no more but he.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Nor I, nor I: but this same one of mine,
Was worth a legion: but all is one.
Pedro, Iaques, go in a doors, Isabella go,
And this good fellow here and I,
Will range this hideous orchard up and down,
Like to two Lions reaved of their young.
Go in a doors, I say.
sp.stage: The Painter and he sits downe.
sp.l: Come let us talk wisely now:
Was thy son murdered?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Aye, sir.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: So was mine.
How dost take it: art thou not sometimes mad?
Is there no tricks that comes before thine eyes?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: O Lord, yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Art a Painter? canst paint me a tear or a wound,
A groan, or a sigh? canst paint me such a tree as this?

sp.speaker: Paint.
sp.l: Sir, I am sure you have heard of my painting, my name is Bazardo.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Bazardo, afore-god, and excellent fellow. Look you sir,
Do you see, I would have you paint me my Gallery
In your oil colours marted, and draw me five
Years younger than I am. Do ye see sir, let five
Years go, let them go like the Marshall of Spaine.
My wife Isabella standing by me,
With a speaking look to my son Horatio.
Which should intend to this, or some such like purpose:
God bless thee, my sweet son and my hand leaning upon his head thus sir, do you see may it be done?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Very well sir.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Nay, I pray mark me, sir. Then sir, would I have you paint me this tree, this very tree.
Canst paint a doleful cry?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Seemingly, sir.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Nay, it should cry: but all is one.
Well sir, paint me a youth, run through and through with villains swords, hanging upon this tree.
Canst thou draw a murderer

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: I will warrant you sir,
I have the pattern of the most notorious villains that ever lived in all Spaine

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: O, let them be worse, worse: stretch thine Art,
And let their beards be of Iudas his own colour,
And let their eyebrows jutty over in any case observe that.
Then sir, after some violent noise,
sp.p: Bring me forth in my shirt, and my gown under mine arm, with my torch in my hand, and my sword reared up thus: and with these words.
sp.l: What noise is this? Who calls Hieronimo?
May it be done?

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: Yea, sir.
sp.p:
Well sir, then bring me forth, bring me through ally and ally, still with a distracted countenance going a long, and let my hair heave up my night-cap.
Let the clouds scowl, make the Moon dark, the Stars extinct, the Winds blowing, the Bells tolling, the Owl shrieking, the Toads croaking, the Minutes jeering, and the Clock striking twelve.
And then at last, sir, starting, behold a man hanging: And tottering, and tottering as you know the wind will weave a man, and I with a trice to cut him down.
And looking upon him by the advantage of my torch, find it to be my son Horatio.
sp.l: There you may a passion, there you may show a passion.
Draw me like old Priam of Troy,
Crying, the house is a fire, the house is a fire
As the torch over my head. Make me curse,
Make me rave, make me cry, make me mad,
Make me well again, make me curse hell,
Invocate heaven, and in the end, leave me
In a trance, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Pain.
sp.l: And is this the end.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: O no, there is no end: the end is death and madness,
As I am never better than when I am mad,
Then methinks I am a brave fellow,
Then I do wonders: But reason abuseth me,
And there is the torment, there is the hell.
At the last, sir, bring me to one of the murderers,
Were he as strong as Hector, thus would I
Tear and drag him up and I down.
sp.stage: He beates the Painter in, then comes out againe with a Booke in his hand.

l.foreign: Vindicta mihi.

sp.l: Aye, heaven will be revenged of every ill,
Nor will they suffer murder unrepaid:
Then stay Hieronimo, attend their will,
For mortal men may not appoint their time.

l.foreign: Perscelus semper tuinm est sceleribus iter.

sp.l: Strike, and strike home, where wrong is offered thee,
For evils unto ills conductors be.
And death's the worst of resolution.
For he that thinks with patience to contend,
To quiet life, his life shall easily end.

l.foreign: Fata si miseros iuuant habes salutem:
Fata si vitam negant, habes sepulchrum.

sp.l: If Destiny thy miseries do ease,
Then hast thou health, and happy shalt thou be:
If destiny deny thee life Heironimo
Yet shalt thou be assured of a tomb:
If neither, yet let this thy comfort be,
Heaven covereth him that hath no burial,
And to conclude, I will revenge his death,
But how? not as the vulgar wits of men,
With open, but inevitable ills:
As by a secret, yet a certain mean,
Which under kindship will be cloaked best.
Wise men will take their opportunity,
Closely and safely fitting things to time:
But in extremes advantage hath no time.
And therefore all times fit not for revenge:
Thus therefore will I rest me in unrest,
Dissembling quiet in unquietness,
Not seeming that I know their villainies:
That my simplicity may make them think,
That ignorantly I will let all slip:
For ignorance I wot, and well they know,

l.foreign: Remedsum malorum iners est.

sp.l: Nor aught avails it me to menace them,
Who as a wintry storm upon a plain,
Will bear me down with their nobility.
No, no, Hieronimo, thou must enjoin
Thine eyes to observation, and thy tongue
To milder speeches, than thy spirit affords,
Thy heart to patience, and thy hands to rest,
Thy Cap to courtesy, and thy knee to bow,
Till to revenge, thou know when, where, and how.
How now, what noise, what coil is that you keep?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here are a sort of poor Petitioners,
That are importunate if it shall please you sir,
That you should plead their cases to the King.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: That I should plead their several actions,
Why let them enter, and let me see them.

div1.stage: Enter three Citizens, and an olde man.

sp.l: So I tell you this for learning and for law,
There is not any advocate in Spaine,
That can prevail, or will take half the pain,
That he will in pursuit of equity.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Come near you men that thus importune me,
Now must I bear a face of gravity,
For thus I used before my Marshalship,
To plead in causes as Corrigedor.
Come on sirs, what is the matter?
Sir an Action.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Of Battery?
Mine of debt.
Give place.
No sir, mine is an action of the case.
Mine an Eiectione firma by a Lease.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Content you sirs, are you determined,
That I should plead your several actions?
Aye sir, and here is my declaration,
And here is my band.
And here is my lease.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: But wherefore stands yon silly man so mute,
With mournful eyes and hands to heaven upreared?
Come hither Father, let me know thy cause?
O worthy sir, my cause but slightly known,
May move the hearts of warlike Myrmidons,
And melt the Corsic Rocks with ruthful tears.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Say Father, tell me what is thy suit?

sp.speaker: Senix.
sp.l: No sir, could my woes
Give way unto my most distressful words,
Then should I not in Paper, as you see,
with Ink bewray, what blood began in me.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: What is here? the humble Supplication
Of Don Bazulto for his murdered Son?

sp.speaker: Senix.
sp.l: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: No sir, it was my murdered Son, O my son,
O my son, O my son Horatio:
But mine, or thine, Bazulto be content.
Here take my Handkercher and wipe thine eyes,
Whiles wretched I, in thy mishaps may see,
The lively portrait of my dying self.
sp.stage: He draweth out a bloudie Napkin.
sp.l: O no, not this, Horatio this was thine,
And when I dyed it in thy dearest blood,
This was a token twixt thy soul and me,
That of thy death revenged I should be.
But here, take this, and this, what my purse?
Aye this and that, and all of them are thine:
For all as one are our extremities.
O, see the kindness of Hieronimo.
This gentleness shows him a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: See, see, O see thy shame Hieronimo,
See here a loving Father to his son:
Behold the sorrows and the sad laments,
That he delivereth for his Son's decease.
If loves effects so strives in lesser things,
If love enforce such moods in meaner wits,
If love express such power in poor estates:
Hieronimo, when as a raging Sea,
Tossed with the wind and tide over-turnest then
The upper billows course of waves to keep,
Whilst lesser waters labour in the deep:
Then shamest thou not Hieronimo to neglect,
The sweet revenge of thy Horatio?
Though on this earth Justice will not be found:
I will down to hell, and in this passion,
Knock at the dismal gates of Pluto's Court,
Getting by force as once Alcides
A troupe of Furies and tormenting Hags,
To torture Don Lorenzo and the rest:
Yet least the triple headed Porter should,
Deny my passage to the slimy strand,
The Thracian Poet thou shalt counterfeit:
Come old Father be my Orpheus
And if thou canst no notes upon the Harp,
Then sound the burden of thy sore hearts grief,
Till we do gain that Proserpine may grant,
Revenge on them that murdered my Son.
Then will I rent and tear them thus, and thus,
Shivering their limbs in pieces with my teeth.
O sir my Declaration.
Save my bond.
Save my bound.
Alas my lease, it cost me ten pound,
And you my Lord have torn the same.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: That cannot be, I gave them never a wound,
Show me one drop of blood fall from the same:
How is it possible I should stay it then?
Tush no, run after, catch me if you can.

div1.stage: Exeunt all but the olde man.
Bazulto remaines till Hieronimo enters againe, who staring him in the face, speaketh.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: And art thou come, Horatio from the depth,
To ask for justice in this upper earth?
To tell thy father thou art unrevenged,
To wring more tears from Isabellas eyes:
Whose lights are dimmed with over-long laments.
Go back my son, complain to Eacus,
For here is no justice, gentle boy be gone:
For justice is exiled from the earth
Hieronimo will bear thee company.
Thy mother cries on righteous Radamant,
For just revenge against the murderers.

sp.speaker: Senex.
sp.l: Alas my Lord. whence springs this troubled speech?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: But let me look on my Horatio:
Sweet Boy, art thou changed in deaths black shade?
Had Proserpine, no pity on thy youth?
But suffered thy fair crimson coloured spring,
With withered winter to be blasted thus?
Horatio, thou art older than thy father:
Ah ruthless father, that favour thus transforms.

sp.speaker: Baz.
sp.l: Ah my good Lord, I am not your young son.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: What, not my son? thou then, a fury art,
Sent from the empty Kingdom of black night,
To summon me to make appearance
Before grim Minos and just Radamant.
To plague Hieronimo, that is remiss,
And seeks not vengeance for Horatios death.
I am a greed man, and not a Ghost,
That came for justice for my murdered Son.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Aye, now I know thee, now thou namest my Son:
Thou art the lively image of my grief,
Within thy face my sorrows I may see.
Thy eyes are gummed with tears, thy cheeks are wan,
Thy forehead troubled, and thy muttering lips
Murmur sad words, abruptly broken off,
By force of windy sighs thy spirit breathes,
And all this sorrow riseth for thy Son:
And self same sorrow feele I for my Son.
Come in old man, thou shalt to Isabell,
Lean on my arm: I thee, thou me, shalt stay,
And thou, and I, and she will sing a song:
Three parts in one, but all of discords framed,
Talk not of cords, but let us now be gone,
For with a cord, Horatio was slain.

div1.stage: Enter King of Spaine, the Duke, Vice-roy, and Lorenzo, Balthazar, Don Pedro, and Bel-imperia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Go, Brother it is the Duke of Castiles cause, salute the Vice-roy in our name.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.l: Go forth Don Pedro, for thy Nephews sake,
And greet the Duke of Castile.

sp.speaker: Pedr.
sp.l: It shall be sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And now to meet these Portagues,
For as we now are, so sometimes were these,
Kings and Commanders of the Western Indies.
Welcome brave Vice-roy to the Court of Spaine,
And welcome all his honourable train.
It is not unknown to us, for why ye come,
Or have so kingly crossed the Seas:
Sufficeth it in this we note the troth,
And more than common love you lend to us.
So is it that mine honourable Niece,
For it beseems us now that it be known,
Already is betrothed to Balthazar:
And by appointment and our condescent,
Tomorrow are they to be married.
To this intent we entertain thyself,
Thy followers, their pleasure, and our peace:
Speak men of Portingale, shall it be so?
If Aye, say so: if not, say flatly no.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Renowned King, I come not as thou thinkest
With doubtful followers, unresolved men,
But such as have upon thine articles,
Confirmed thy motion and contented me.
Know sovereign, I come to solemnise
The marriage of thy beloved Niece,
Fair Bel-imperia with my Balthazar.
With thee my Son, whom sith I live to see
Here take my Crown, I give it her and thee:
And let me live a solitary life,
In ceaseless prayers,
To think how strangely heaven hath thee preserved.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: See brother, see, how nature strives in him,
Come worthy Vice-roy and accompany
Thy friend, with thine extremities:
A place more private fits this princely mood.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Or here or where your Highness thinks it good.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Nay stay Lorenzo, let me talk with you,
Seest thou this entertainment of these Kings?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I do my Lord, and joy to see the same.

sp.speaker: Cas
sp.l: And knowest thou why this meeting is?

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.l: For her my Lord, whom Balthazar doth love,
And to confirm their promised marriage.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: She is thy Sister.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who Bel-imperia, Aye my gracious Lord,
And this is the day, that I have longed so happily to see.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Thou wouldst be loath that any fault of thine,
Should intercept her in her happiness.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Heavens will not let Lorenzo err so much,

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Why then Lorenzo listen to my words,
It is suspected and reported too,
That thou Lorenzo wrongest Hieronimo.
And in his suites towards his Majesty,
Still keeps him back, and seeks to cross his suit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That I my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I tell thee Son myself have heard it said,
When to my sorrow I have been ashamed
To answer for thee, though thou art my Son,
Lorenzo, knowest thou not the common love,
And kindness that Hieronimo hath won,
By his deserts within the Court of Spaine?
Or seest thou not the King my brothers care,
In his behalf, and to procure his health?
Lorenzo, shouldst thou thwart his passions,
And he exclaim against thee to the King,
What honour wert in this assembly,
Or what a scandal wert among the Kings,
To hear Hieronimo exclaim on thee?
Tell me, and look thou tell me truly too,
Whence grows the ground of this report in Court?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: My Lord it lies not in Lorenzos power
To stop the vulgar liberal of their tongues:
A small advantage makes a water breach,
And no man lives that long contenteth all.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Myself have seen thee busy to keep back,
Him and his supplications from the King.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Yourself my Lord. hath seen his passions,
That ill beseemed the presence of a King:
And for I pitied him in his distress,
I held him thence with kind and courteous words,
As free from malice to Hieronimo,
As to my soul my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hieronimo my son, mistakes thee then.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: My gracious Father, believe me so he doth,
But what is a silly man distract in mind
To think upon the murder of his son:
Alas, how easy is it for him to err?
But for his satisfaction and the worlds,
It were good my Lord. that Hieronimo and I,
Were reconciled, if he misconster me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Lorenzo, thou hast said, it shall be so,
Go one of you and call Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Come Bel-imperia, Balthazars content,
My sorrows ease and sovereign of my bliss,
Sith heaven hath ordained thee to be mine:
Disperse those clouds and melancholy looks,
And clear them up with those thy Sun bright eyes,
Wherein my hope and heavens fair beauty lies.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My looks my Lord, are fitting for my love,
Which new begun, can show no brighter yet.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: New kindled flames should burn as morning Sun.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But not too fast, lest heat and all be done.
I see my Lord my Father.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Truce my love, I will go salute him.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Welcome Balthazar, welcome brave Prince
The pledge of Castiles peace:
And welcome Bel-imperia, how now girl?
Why comest thou sadly to salute us thus?
Content thyself for I am satisfied,
It is not now as when Andrea lived,
We have forgotten and forgiven that,
And thou art graced with a happier love,
But Balthazar here comes Hieronimo.
I will have a word with him.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: And wheres the Duke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yonder.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Even so: what new device have they devised trow?
Pocas Palabras, mild as the Lamb,
Is it I will be revenged? no, I am not the man.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Welcome Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Welcome Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Welcome Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: My Lords I thank you for Horatio.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hieronimo, the reason that I sent
To speak with you, is this.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: What, so short?
Then I will be gone, I thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Nay, stay Hieronimo: go call him son.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hieronimo, my father craves a word with you.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: With me sir? why my Lord. I thought you had done.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No, would he had.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hiero, I hear you find yourself aggrieved at my Son,
Because you have not access unto the King:
And say it is he that intercepts your suits.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Why, is not this a miserable thing my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hieronimo, I hope you have no cause,
And would be loath that one of your deserts,
Should once have reason to suspect my Son,
Considering how I think of you myself.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: Your son Lorenzo, whom my noble Lord,
The hope of Spaine, mine honourable friend?
Grant me the combat of them, if they dare.
I will meet him face to face to tell me so.
These be the scandalous reports of such,
As loves not me, and hate my Lord too much.
Should I suspect Lorenzo would prevent,
Or cross my suit, that loved my Son so well.
My Lord, I am ashamed it should be said.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hieronimo, I never gave you cause.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: My good Lord, I know you did not.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: There then pause, and for the satisfaction of the world,
Hieronimo frequent my homely house,
The Duke of Castile Ciprians ancient seat,
And when thou wilt, use me, my son, and it:
But here before Prince Balthazar and me,
Embrace each other, and be perfect friends.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Aye marry my Lord, and shall.
Friends (quoth he) see, I will be friends with you all:
Specially with you my lovely Lord,
For divers causes it is sit for us,
That we be friends, the world is suspicious,
And men may think what we imagine not.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Why this is friendly done Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And that I hope old grudges are forgot.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: What else, it were a shame it should not be so.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Come on Hieronimo,at my request,
Let us entreat your company today.

sp.speaker: Hiro.
sp.l: Your Lordships to command,
Pha: keep your way.

l.foreign: chi ma fa? Pui Correzza Che non sule
Tradito niba otrade vule.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Awake Erictha, Cerberus awake,
Solicit Pluto gentle Proserpine,
To combat Achinon and Erickus in hell.
For ne'er by Styx, and Phlegeton:
Nor ferried Caron to the fiery lakes,
Such fearful sights, as poor Andrea sees
Revenge awake.

sp.speaker: Reueng.
sp.l: Awake, for why?

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Awake Revenge, for thou art ill advised,
To sleeps away, what thou art warned to watch.

sp.speaker: Reu.
sp.l: Content thyself, and do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Awake Revenge, if love, as love hath had,
Have yet the power or prevalence in hell,
Hieronimo, with Lorenzo is joined in league,
And intercepts our passage to revenge:
Awake Revenge, or we are woe begone.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Thus worldlings ground what they have dreamed upon,
Content thyself, Andrea, though I sleep,
Yet is my mood soliciting their souls,
Sufficeth thee that poor Hieronimo,
Cannot forget his son Horatio.
Nor dies Revenge, although he sleep a while,
For in unquiet, quietness is found:
And slumbering is a common worldly wile,
Behold Andrea for an instance, how
Revenge hath slept, and then imagine thou,
What it is to be subject to destiny.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Awake, Revenge, reveal this Mystery.

sp.speaker: Reuen.
sp.l: The two first, the nuptial torches bore,
As bright burning as the midday's sun:
But after them doth Hymen hie as fast,
Clothed in Sable, and a Saffron robe,
And blows them out, and quencheth them with blood,
As discontent that things continue so.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Sufficeth me thy meanings understood,
And thanks to thee and those infernal powers,
That will not tolerate a lovers woe,
Rest thee, for I will sit to see the rest.

sp.speaker: Reunge.
sp.l: Then argue not for thou hast thy request.

sp.speaker: Bel-imperia.
sp.l: IS this the love thou bearst Horatio?
Is this the kindness that thou counterfeits?
Are these the fruits of thine incessant tears?
Hieronimo, are these thy passions?
Thy protestations, and thy deep laments,
That thou wert wont to weary men withal?
O unkind Father, O deceitful world,
With what excuses canst thou show thyself?
With what dishonour, and the hate of men:
From this dishonour and the hate of men:
Thus to neglect the life and loss of him.
Whom both my letters, and thine own belief,
Assures thee to be causeless slaughtered?
Hieronimo, for shame Hieronimo:
Be not a history to after times,
Of such ingratitude unto thy Son.
Unhappy Mother of such children then:
But monstrous Father, to forget so soon
The death of those, whom they with care and cost
Have tendered so, thus careless should be lost.
Myself a stranger in respect of thee,
So loved his life, as still I wish their deaths:
Nor shall his death be unrevenged by me.
Although I bear it out for fashions sake,
For here I swear in sight of heaven and earth,
Shouldst thou neglect the love thou shouldst retain,
And give it over, and devise no more,
Myself should send their hateful souls to hell,
That wrought his downfall with extremest death.

sp.speaker: Hiero.
sp.l: But may it be that Bel-imperia,
Vows such revenge as she hath deigned to say:
Why then I see that heaven applies our drift,
And all the Saints do sit soliciting,
For vengeance on those cursed murtherers
Madam it is true, and now I find it so,
I found a Letter written in your name,
And in that Letter, how Horatio died.
Pardon, O pardon Bel-imperia,
My fear and care in not believing it,
Nor think, I thoughtless think upon a mean,
To let his death be unrevenged at full:
And here I vow, so you but give consent,
And will conceal my resolution:
I will ere long determine of their deaths,
That causeless thus have murdered my son.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hieronimo, I will consent, conceal,
And aught that may effect for thine avail,
Join with thee to revenge Horatios death.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: On then, whatsoever I devise,
Let me entreat you grace my practises?
For why, the plot's already in mine head.
Here they are.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: How now Hieronimo, What courting Bel-imperia?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Aye my Lord, such courting as I promise you
She hath my heart, but you my Lord have hers.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But now, Hieronimo, or never we are to entreat your help.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: My help, why my good Lords assure yourselves of me.
For you have given me cause, Aye by my faith have you.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: It pleased you at the entertainment of the Ambassador,
To grace the king so much as with a show:
Now were your study so well furnished,
As for the passing of the first nights sport
To entertain my father with the like:
Or any such like pleasing motion,
Assure yourself it would content them well.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Aye, this is all.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Why then I will fit you, say no more.
When I was young I gave my mind,
And plied myself to fruitless Poetry:
Which though it profit the Professor naught,
Yet is it passing pleasing to the world.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And how for that?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Marry, my good Lord, thus.
And yet methink you are too quick with us.
When in Tolledo, there I studied,
It was my chance to write a Tragedy,
See here my Lords.
Which long forgot, I found this other day,
Now would your Lordships favour me so much,
As but to grace me with your acting it,
I mean each one of you to play a part,
Assure you it will prove most passing strange,
And wondrous plausible to that assembly.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: What? would you have us play a Tragedy?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Why, Nero thought it no disparagement:
And Kings and Emperors have taken delight,
To make experience of their wits in plays.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay be not angry good Hieronimo,
The Prince but asked a question.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: In faith Hieronimo, if you be in earnest,
I will make one.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And I, another.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Now, my good Lord, could you entreat
Your Sister Bel-imperia to make one,
For what is a play without a woman in it?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Little entreaty shall serve me Hieronomo,
For I must needs be employed in your play.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Why this is well, I tell you Lordings,
It was determined to have been acted,
By Gentlemen and scholars too:
Such as could tell what to speak.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: And now it shall be said, by Princes and Courtiers
Such as can tell how to speak:
If as it is our Country manner,
You will but let us know the Argument.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: That shall I roundly, the Chronicles of Spaine,
Record this written of a Knight of Rhodes,
He was betrothed and wedded at the length,
To one Perseda, an Italian Dame.
Whose beauty ravished all that her beheld,
Especially the soul of Soliman,
Who at the marriage way the cheesefest guest.
By sundry means sought Soliman to win
Persedas love, and could not gain the same:
Then gan he break his passions to a friend,
One of his Bashawes whom he held full dear,
Her had this Bashaw long solicited,
And saw she was not otherwise to be won,
But by her husbands death, this Knight of Rhodes.
Whom presently by treachery he slew,
She stirred with an exceeding hate therefore,
As cause of this, slew Soliman:
And to escape the Bashawes tyranny,
Did stab herself: and this is the Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O excellent!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But say, Hieronimo, What then became of him
That was the Bashaw?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Marry, thus, moved with remorse of his misdeeds
Ran to a mountain top and hung himself.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: But which of us is to perform that part.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: O, that will I my Lords, make no doubt of it,
I will play the murderer I warrant you,
For I already have conceited that.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: And what shall I?
Great Soliman the Turkish Emperor.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And I?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Erastus the Knight of Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And I?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Perseda, chaste, and resolute.
And here, my Lords, are several abstracts drawn,
For each of you to note your parts,
And act it as occasion's offered you.
You must provide a Turkish cap,
A black moustache, and a Falchion.
You, with a Cross, like a Knight of Rhodes.
And Madam, you must attire yourself,
Like Phoebe, Flora, or the huntress,
Which to your discretion shall seem best.
And as for me my Lords, I will look to one,
And with the ransom that the Vice-roy sent,
So furnish and perform this Tragedy,
As all the world shall say Hieronimo,
Was liberal in gracing of it so.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Hieronimo, methinks a Comedy were better.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: A Comedy, fie, Comedies are fit for common wits,
But to present a Kingly troupe with-all,
Give me a stately written Tragedy.
Tragedia cother nato, fitting Kings,
Containing matter, and not common things.
My Lords, all this must be performed,
As fitting for the first nights revelling.
The Italian Tragedians were so sharpe of wit,
That in one hours meditation,
They would perform anything in action.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And well it may, for I have seen the like
In Paris, amongst the French Tragedians.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: In Paris, mass and well remembered,
There is one thing more that rests for us to do.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: What is that Hieronimo forget not anything.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Each one of us must act his part,
In unknown languages,
That it may breed the more variety.
As you, my Lord, in Latin, I, in Greek,
You in Italian, and for because I know
That Bel-imperia hath practised the French,
In courtly French shall all her phrases be.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You mean to try my cunning then Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: But this will be a mere confusion,
And hardly shall we all be understood.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: It must be so, for the conclusion
Shall prove the invention, and all was good:
And I myself in an Oration,
And with a strange and wondrous show besides
That I will have there behind a curtain,
Assure yourself shall make the matter known.
And all shall be concluded in one Scene,
For there is no pleasure taken in tediousness.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: How like you this?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why thus, my Lord, we must resolve,
To sooth his humours up.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: On then, Hieronimo, farewell till soon.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: You will ply this gear?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Aye, why so. Now shall I see the fall of Babylon,
Wrought by the heavens in this confusion.
And if the world like not this Tragedy,
Hard is the hap of old Hieronimo.
Tell me no more, O monstrous homicides,
Since neither piety nor pity moves
The King to justice or compassion:
I will revenge myself upon this place,
Where they murdered my beloved son.
Down with these branches and those loathsome bows,
Of this unfortunate and fatal Pine.
Down with them Isabella, rent them up,
And burn the roots from whence the rest is sprung.
I will not leave a root, a stalk, a tree,
A bough, a branch, a blossom, nor a leaf,
No, not an herb within this garden plot.
Accursed complot of my misery,
Fruitless for ever may this garden be.
Barren the earth, and blissless whosoever
Imagines not to keep it unmanured.
An Eastern wind commixed with noisome airs,
Shall blast the plants and the young saplings,
The earth with serpents shall be pestered,
And passengers for fear to be infect,
Shall stand aloof, and looking at it, tell:
There murdered, died the son of Isabell,
Aye, here he died, and here I him embrace.
See where his Ghost solicits with his wounds,
Revenge on her that should revenge his death,
Hieronimo, make haste to see thy son,
For sorrow and despair hath cited me,
To hear Horatio plead with Radamant,
Make haste Hieronimo, to hold excused.
Thy negligence in pursuit of their deaths,
Whose hateful wrath bereaved him of his breath.
Ah ha, thou doest delay their deaths,
Forgives the murderers of thy noble son,
And none but I bestir me to no end,
And as I curse this tree from further fruit,
So shall my womb be cursed for his sake,
And with this weapon will I wound the breast,
The hapless breast that gave Horatio suck.

div1.stage: Enter Hieronimo, he knocks vp the curtain.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: How now, Hieronimo, where is your fellows,
That you take all this pain?

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: O sir, it is for the Authors credit,
To look that all things may go well:
But good my Lord. let me entreat your Grace,
To give the King the copy of the Play:
This is the Argument of what we show.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I will, Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: One thing more, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Let me entreat your grace,
That when the train are past into the gallery,
You would vouchsafe to throw me down the key.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I will Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: What are you ready Balthazar?
Bring a chair and a cushion for the King.
Well done Balthazar, hang up the title:
Our scene is Rhodes, what is your beard on?

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Half on, the other is in my hand.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Dispatch for shame, are you so long?
Bethink thyself Hieronimo,
Recall thy wits, recount thy former wrongs
Thou hast received by murder of thy son.
And lastly, not least, how Isabell,
Once his mother and thy dearest wife:
All woe begone for him hath slain herself.
Behooves thee then Hieronimo to be revenged,
The plot is laid of dire revenge,
On then Hieronimo, pursue revenge:
For nothing wants but acting of revenge.

div1.stage: Enter Spanish King, Vice-roy, Duke of Castile, and their traine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now Viceroy, shall we see the Tragedy,
Of Soliman the Turkish Emperor:
Performed of pleasure by your Son the Prince,
My Nephew Don Lorenzo, and my Niece.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Who, Bel-imperia?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Aye, and Hieronimo our Marshall.
At whose request, they deign to do it themselves.
These be our pastimes in the Court of Spaine.
Here brother, you shall be the Bookkeeper.
This is the Argument of that they show.

note.l: in sundry Languages, was thought good to be set down in English more largely, for the easier understanding to every public Reader.

sp.speaker: Balthazar.
sp.l: BAshaw, that Rhodes is ours, yield heavens the honour,
And holy Mahomet our sacred Prophet:
And be thou graced with every excellence,
That Soliman can give, or thou desire.
But thy desert in conquering Rhodes, is less,
Than in reserving this fair Christian Nymph
Perseda blissful lamp of excellence:
Whose eyes compel like powerful Adamant,
The warlike heart of Soliman to wait.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: See Vice-Roy, that is Balthazar your Son,
That represents the Emperor Soliman:
How well he acts his amorous passion.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Aye Bel-imperia hath taught him that.

sp.speaker: Castile.
sp.l: That is because his mind runs all on Bel-imperia.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: What ever joy earth yields betide your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Earth yields no joy, without Persedas love.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Then let Persedas on your grace attend.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: She shall not wait on me, but I on her:
Drawn by the influence of her lights, I yield.
But let my friend the Rhodian Knight come forth,
Erasto, dearer than my life to me,
That he may see Perseda my beloved.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here comes Lorenzo, look up on the plot,
And tell me brother, what part plays he?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ah my Erasta, welcome to Perseda.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Thrice happy is Erasto, that thou livest,
Rhodes loss is nothing to Erastoes joy,
Sith his Perseda lives, his life survives.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Ah, Bashaw, here is love betwixt Erasto,
And fair Perseda, sovereign of my soul.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Remove Erasto mighty Soliman,
And then Perseda, will be quickly won.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Erasto is my friend, and while he lives,
Perseda never will remove her love.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Let not Erasto live to grieve great Soliman.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Dear is Erasto in our princely eye.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: But if he be your rival let him die.

sp.speaker: Bal.
sp.l: Why let him die, so love commandeth me,
Yet grieve I that Erasto should so die.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Erasto, Soliman saluteth thee,
And lets thee wit by me his highness will:
Which is, thou shouldst be thus employed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Aye me Erasto, see Soliman Erasto's slain.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Yet liveth Soliman to comfort thee.
Fair Queen of beauty, let not favour die,
But with a gracious eyes behold his grief,
That with Persedaes beauty is increased?
If by Persedaes grief be not released.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Tyrant, desist soliciting vain suites,
Relentless are mine ears to thy laments,
As thy butcher is pitiless and base,
Which seized on my Erasto, harmless Knight.
Yet by thy power thou thinkest to command,
And to thy power Perseda doth obey:
But were she able, thus she would revenge
Thy treacheries on thee ignoble Prince:
And on herself, she would be thus revenged

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well said old Marshall, this was bravely done.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: But Bel-imperia plays Perseda well.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Were this in earnest Bel-imperia,
You would be better to my Son then so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But now what follows for Hieronimo.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Marry, this follows for Hieronimo.
Here break we off our sundry languages,
And thus conclude I in our vulgar tongue.
Happily you think, but bootless are your thoughts:
That this is fabulously counterfeit
And that we do as all Tragedians do.
To die today for (fashioning our Scene)
The death of Aiax, or some Roman Peer,
And in a minute starting up again,
Revive to please tomorrow's audience.
No Princes: know I am Hieronimo,
The hopeless father of a hapless Son,
Whose tongue is tuned to tell his latest tale,
Not to excuse gross errors in the Play,
I see your looks urge instance of these words,
Behold the reason urging me to this.
See here my show, look on this spectacle:
Here lay my hope, and here my hope hath end:
Here lay my heart, and here my heart was slain:
Here lay my treasure, here my treasure lost:
Here lay my bliss, and here my bliss bereft.
But hope, heart, treasure, joy, and bliss:
All fled, failed, died, yea all decayed with this.
From forth these wounds came breath that gave me life,
They murdered me that made these fatal marks:
The cause was love, whence grew this mortal hate.
The hate Lorenzo and young Balthazar:
The love my son to Bel-imperia.
But night the coverer of accursed crimes,
With pitchy silence hushed these traitors harms,
And lent them leave, for they had sorted leisure,
To take advantage in my garden plot,
Upon my Son, my dear Horatio:
There merciless they butchered up my boy,
In black dark night, to pale dim cruel death.
He shrikes, I heard, and yet methinks I hear,
His dismal out-cry echo in the air:
With soonest speed I hasted to the noise,
Where hanging on a tree I found my son.
Through girt with wounds, and slaughtered as you see,
And grieved I (think you) at this spectacle?
Speak Portagues, whose loss resembles mine,
If thou canst weep upon thy Balthazar?
It is like I wailed for my Horatio.
And you my Lord. whose reconciled son,
Marched in a net, and thought himself unseen,
And rated me for brain-sick lunacy,
Which God amend, that mad Hieronimo,
How can you brook our plays Catastrophe?
And here behold this bloody hand-kercher
Which at Horatios death, I weeping dipped,
Within the river of his bleeding wounds:
It as propitious, see I have reserved,
And never hath it left my bloody heart,
Soliciting remembrance of my vow.
With these, O these accursed murderers,
Which now performed, my heart is satisfied.
And to this end the Bashaw I became,
That might revenge me on Lorenzoes life:
Who therefore was appointed to the part,
And was to represent the Knight of Rhodes,
That I might kill him more conveniently.
So Vice-roy was this Balthazar thy son,
That Soliman which Bel-imperia,
In person of Perseda murdered:
Soly appointed to that tragic part,
That she might slay him that offended her.
Poor Bel-imperia missed her part in this,
For though the story saith she should have died,
Yet I of kindness, and of care to her,
Did otherwise determine of her end.
But love of him whom they did hate too much,
Did urge her resolution to be such.
And Princes, now behold Hieronimo,
Author, and actor in this Tragedy:
Bearing his latest fortune in his fist:
And will as resolute conclude his part,
As any of the actors gone before.
And Gentles, thus I end my play,
Urge no more words, I have no more to say.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O hearken Vice-roy, hold Hieronimo,
Brother, my Nephew, and thy son are slain.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: We are betrayed, my Balthazar is slain,
Break ope the doors, run save Hieronimo.
sp.stage: They breake in, and hold Hieronimo
sp.l: Hieronimo, Do but inform the King of these events,
Upon mine honour thou shalt have no harm.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Vice-roy, I will not trust thee with my life,
Which I this day have offered to my Son:
Accursed wretch, why stayest thou him that was resolved to die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Speak Traitor, damned, bloody murderer speak,
For now I have thee, I will make thee speak,
Why hast thou done this undeserving deed?

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Why hast thou murdered my Balthazar?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Why hast thou butchered both my children thus?

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: But are you sure they are dead?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Aye, slave, too sure.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: What and yours too?

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Aye, all are dead, not one of them survive.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Nay, then I care not, come, and we shall be friends
Let us lay our heads together,
See here is a goodly noose will hold them all.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: O damned Devil, how secure he is.

sp.speaker: Hier.
sp.l: Secure, why doest thou wonder at it.
I tell thee Vice-roy, this day I have seen revenged,
And in that sight am grown a prouder Monarch,
Than ever fate under the Crown of Spaine:
Had I as many lives as there be Stars,
As many Heavens to go to, as those lives,
I would give them all, I and my soul to boot,
But I would see thee ride in this red poole.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Speak, Who were thy confederates in this?

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: That was thy daughter Bel-imperia,
For by her hand my Balthazar was slain:
I saw her stab him

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: O good words, as dear to me was my Horatio,
As yours, or yours, or yours my Lord. to you.
My guiltless son was by Lorenzo slain,
And by Lorenzo, and that Balthazar,
Am I at last revenged thoroughly.
Upon whose souls may heavens be yet revenged,
With greater far than these afflictions.
Methinks since I grew inward with revenge
I cannot look with scorn enough on death.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What doest thou mock us slave, bring torture forth

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Do, do, do, and mean time I will torture you
You had a son (as I take it) and your son,
Should have been married to your daughter: ha, was it not so?
You had a son too, he was my Lieges Nephew.
He was proud and politic, had he lived,
He might a come to wear the crown of Spaine,
I think it was so: it was I that killed him,
Look you this same hand, it was it that stabbed
His heart, Do you see this hand?
For one Horatio, if you ever knew him
A youth, one that they hanged up in his fathers garden:
One that did force your valiant son to yield,
While your more valiant son did take him prisoner:

sp.speaker: Vis.
sp.l: Be deaf my senses, I can hear no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fall heaven, and cover us with thy sad ruins.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Roll all the world within thy pitchy cloud.

sp.speaker: Hie.
sp.l: Now do I applaud what I have acted.

l.foreign: Nunck mers cade manus

sp.l: Now to express the rupture of my part,
First take my tongue, and afterwards my heart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O monstrous resolution of a wretch,
See Vice-roy, he hath bitten forth his tongue,
Rather than to reveal what we required.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Yet can he write.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And if in this he satisfy us not,
We will devise the extremest kind of death,
That ever was invented for a wretch.
sp.stage: Then he makes signes for a knife to mend his pen.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O, he would have a knife to mend his pen.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Here, and advise thee that thou write the troth,
Look to my brother, save Hieronimo.
sp.stage: He with a knife stabs the Duke and himselfe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What age hath ever heard such monstrous deeds?
My brother and the whole succeeding hope,
That Spaine expected after my decease,
Go bear his body hence that we may mourn,
The loss of our beloved brothers death.
That he may be entombed whatere befall,
I am the next the nearest last of all.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: And thou Don Pedro do the like for us,
Take up our hapless son untimely slain:
Set me with him, and he with woeful me,
Upon the maine mast of a ship unmanned,
And let the wind and tide hale me along,
To Sallas barking and untamed grief:
Or to the loath some poole of Acheron,
To weep my want for my sweet Balthazar,
Spaine hath no refuge for a Portingale.

div1.stage: The Trumpets sound a dead march, the King of Spaine mourning after his brothers body, and the king of Portingale bearing the body of his sonne.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Aye, now my hopes have end in their effects,
When blood and sorrow finish my desires,
Horatio murdered in his Fathers bower,
Vile Serberine by Pedringano slain:
False Pedringano hanged by quaint device,
Fair Isabella, by herself misdone,
Prince Balthazar by Bel-imperia stabbed,
The Duke of Castile and his wicked son,
Both done to death by old Hieronimo.
My Bel-imperia fallen as Dido fell,
And good Hieronimo slain by himself:
Aye, these were spectacles to please my soul.
Now will I beg at lovely Proserpine,
That by the virtue of her Princely doom,
I may consort my friends in pleasing sort,
And on my foes work just and sharpe revenge.
I will lead my friend Horatio through those fields,
Where never dying wars are still inured.
I will lead fair Isabella to that train,
Where pity weeps, but never feeleth pain.
I will lead my Bel-imperia to those joys,
That Vestal Virgins, and fair Queens possess,
I will lead Hieronimo where Orpheus plays,
Adding sweet pleasure to eternal days.
But say Revenge, for thou must help or none,
Against the rest how shall my hate be shown?

sp.speaker: Reuenge.
sp.l: This hand shall hale them down to deepest hell,
Where nought but furies, bugs and tortures dwell.

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: Then sweet Revenge do this at my request,
Let me be judge, and doom them to unrest.
Let loose poor Titius from the Vultures gripe,
And let Don Ciprian supply his room.
place Don Lorenzo on Ixions wheel,
And let the Lovers endless pains surcease:
Iuno forgets old wrath and grants him ease.
Hang Balthazar about Chineras neck
And let him there bewail his bloody love,
Repining at our joys that are above.
Let Serberine go roll the fatal stone,
And take from Siciphus his endless moan.
False Pedringaco for his treachery,
Let him be dragged through boiling Acheron,
And there live dying still in endless flames,
Blaspheming Gods and all their holy names.

sp.speaker: Reunenge.
sp.l: Then haste we down to meet thy friends and foes,
To place thy friends in ease, the rest in woes.
For here, though death hath end their misery,
I will there begin their endless Tragedy.
